In 2005, the Government and the international development partners decided to convert 
the  annual  Consultative  Group  meetings  into  the  Philippines  development  forum  (PDF).  The 
PDF  provides  an  opportunity  for  ongoing  dialogue,  involving  other  stakeholders,  such  as  civil 
society, the private sector, and the academic community. The Government convenes the PDF 
to  discuss

with the Government and to provide an impetus to MTPDP implementation. Currently the PDF 
has  seven  working  groups,  each  focusing  on  priority  areas  of  the  Government’s  development 
agenda (Figure 1). In March 2006, the Government agreed with the World Bank to use the PDF 
agenda as the basis for a World Bank development policy loan. Shortly after the workshop, the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  was  invited  to  join  the  process  and  to  prepare  the  reform 
agenda  through  the  DPSP.  The  agenda  was  refined  and  modified  through  subsequent  PDF 
workshops  in  2007  and  2008  to  reflect  the  Government’s  new  priorities  and  medium-term 
challenges. When the DPSP was first formulated in 2006, it was anchored in four core areas of 
the  PDF:  fiscal  consolidation,  governance,  investment  climate  and  infrastructure,  and  social 
progress.  At  the  request  of  the  Government,  subprograms  2  and  3  of  the  DPSP  will  continue 
with these four areas and add rural development as part of the investment climate component 
reflecting the Government’s and ADB’s increased focus on improving the investment climate.

11. 
Best  Macroeconomic  Performance  in  30  Years.  Data  from  the  National  Statistical 
Coordination Board indicates economic growth at 7.2% in 2007, the highest on record for almost 
30  years.  It  is  among  the  highest  growth  rates  in  the  Asian  region.  Growth  has  been  broad-
based with services the fastest growing sector with a growth rate of 8.2% in 2007, contributing 
to  56%  of  economic  growth,  followed  by  industry  and  agriculture.  On  the  demand  side, 
consumption  remains  an  engine  of  growth  rising  by  5.9%  in  2007  contributing  to  65%  of 
economic growth. 
 
12. 
Three  Features  of  the  Current  Economic  Growth  Performance.  First,  the  current 
economic expansion is the longest in three decades, with economic growth averaging 5.1% per 
year  since  2000,  compared  with  average  annual  growth  of  2%  in  the  1990s  (Appendix  4). 
Second, the current economic expansion reflects improved economic fundamentals associated 
with  historically  low  inflation  in  2007,  fiscal  consolidation,  declining  public  debt  as  a  share  of 
GDP, current account surplus, and higher total factor productivity growth. In contrast, previous 
expansions  were  associated  with  sharp  macroeconomic  imbalances  including  high  inflation, 
increasing  public  debt,  and  at  times  deterioration  in  the  balance  of  payments.  These  are  all 
features  of  a  boom–bust  business  cycle  not  based  on  economic  fundamentals.  Political

Recovery  of  Investment.  Investment  spending  picked  up  strongly  in 2007  for  the  first 
time  in  10  years,  growing  by  11.8%,  well  above  its  average  annual  growth  rate  of  0.8%  from 
1997  to  2006  (Table  1).  The  upturn  was  driven  by  the  25%  growth  in  public  infrastructure 
spending in 2007. Private sector investment also grew strongly with private construction growing 
by a robust 15.9% compared with negative 1.4% in 2006. Spending on durable equipment grew 
by  4.4%.  Foreign  direct  investment  approvals  (a  measure  of  intended  investment)  doubled  in 
2007 over 2006. Overall, the investment to GDP ratio (in current prices) improved from 14.0% in 
2006 to 14.8% in 2007. Investment growth slowed to 6.6% (year-on-year) in the first quarter of 
2008, primarily due to a 9.5% contraction in public construction. Private construction remained 
robust  growing  by  15.1%.  Also  encouraging  for  investment,  purchases  of  new  durable 
equipment grew by 8.2% in the first quarter of 2008, double the growth rate in 2007. 
 
14. 
Deterioration  of  the  External  Environment.  In  2008,  the  Philippines  economy  has 
been  affected  by  three  adverse  developments  in  the  external  environment:  (i)  impact  of  US 
financial  sector  turbulence,  (ii)  the  US  and  global  economic  slowdown,  and  (iii)  recent 
commodity and fuel price increases. The sharp slowdown in the US economy and turbulence in 
its financial markets is affecting growth conditions in the Philippines. While the economic growth 
rates of the Philippines and other developing economies can and do diverge from the US growth 
rate,  volatility  in  the  US  is  transmitted  to  developing  economies.  The  direct  impact  of  the  US 
financial crisis is limited, but indirect effects are possible through restructuring of balance sheet 
effects of US banks. Possible effects include credit crunch and in recent months rising spreads 
on sovereign and corporate bond issues. The unexpected recent surge in international food and 
energy  prices  has  resulted  in  higher  domestic  inflation  in  2008.  Inflation  hit  a  17-year  high  of 
12.2% in July 2008 on a year-on-year basis, with rice prices up by 43%. ADB staff forecasts for 
inflation suggest a continuation of double-digit food price inflation through to the third quarter of 
2008.  The  economic  growth  rate  of  4.7%  in  the  first  quarter  of  2008  and  4.6%  in  the  second 
quarter of 2008 suggests that these adverse effects are beginning to affect the real economy.

exports  in  value-added  terms  contracted.  These  adverse  developments  have  increased  the

Prudent Fiscal Management. The Government deficit fell to P12.4 billion in 2007 (0.2% 
of  GDP)  from  P64.8  billion  in  2006  (0.9%  of  GDP).  This  fiscal  performance  compares  with  a 
2.7% budget deficit in 2005 and 5.2% in 2003. The consolidated public sector budget essentially 
remained  in  balance  for  a  second  consecutive  year  surpassing  the  medium-term  target  of  a 
balanced budget in 2010 (para. 17). The nonfinancial public sector debt to GDP ratio declined to 
67%, back to its level in the early 1990s (Figure 4). Unlike previous budgets, the reduction in the 
deficit came about through increases in total revenues rather than suppression of expenditures 
(Appendix 5). In March 2006, PDF stakeholders cautioned against disproportionate reliance on 
expenditure cuts rather than revenue collection. Noninterest expenditures increased by 19% in 
the  2007  budget  over  2006  (2005  budget  reenacted),18 aided  by  a  reduction  in  debt  servicing 
costs  of  P36  billion  from  lower  interest  rates  on  public  debt  and  the  peso  exchange  rate 
appreciation.  Spending  on  the  social  sectors  (health  and  education)  and  public  infrastructure 
were  the  main  beneficiaries  of  the  boost  in  spending  in  2007,  with  spending  on  infrastructure 
rising  by  45.4%  assured  by  the  Government’s  commitment  to  earmark  30%  of  incremental 
value-added  tax  revenue  collections  to  the  social  sectors.  On  the  revenue  side,  tax  revenue 
collection increased by 9% over 2006, but fell short of its budget target of 17.3% (para. 18). To 
meet  the  shortfall  in  revenues,  the  Government  accelerated  privatization  of  assets  raising  
P90 billion in proceeds, up from P5 billion in 2006. More than 40% came from privatization of

17. 
Fiscal  Program.  In  2006  the  Government  advanced  the  target  to  achieve  a  balanced 
national budget under the MTPDP by 2 years to 2008, based on the surge in tax revenues in the 
2006  budget  (tax  revenues  grew  1.3  percentage  points  of  GDP  in  2006).  The  2007  budget 
deficit was recorded at 0.2% of GDP, making the 2008 target highly probable. However, much 
has  changed  since  the  end  of  2007.  Global  developments  have  deteriorated  and  these  are 
beginning  to  negatively  impact  the  Philippine  economy,  as  is  the  case  for  the  region.  The 
Government  has  decided,  and  development  partners  concur,  that  the  balanced  budget  target 
should  be  reverted  back  to  2010  to  provide  flexibility  in  fiscal  policy  in  2008  in  the  event 
programs  are  necessary  to  mitigate  the  impact  of  recent  increases  in  food  prices  on  the  poor 
and  to  maintain  priority  spending  programs  if  the  economy  slows  down.  The  Government  is 
targeting a deficit of no more than 1% of GDP in 2008, 0.5% in 2009, and a balanced budget in 
2010.  The  2010  target  is  achievable,  but  requires  increased  efforts  to  raise  tax  revenues  to 
meet the Government’s fiscal program target of 15% of GDP by 2010 (para. 18).

Tax Revenue Performance. BIR cash collection in the first half of 2007 was up 5% over 
the same period in 2006, and up 9% for the entire year, short of the 2007 budget target for BIR 
of a 17.3% increase over 2006. BOC also experienced a shortfall in collection from its budget 
target. Government and ADB assessments of revenue performance in 2007 show that the tax

year, resulting in lower value-added tax and customs duties collected on imported products than

further  effort  to  raise  tax  revenues.  Reaching  the  Government’s  revised  medium-term  tax 
revenue  target  of  15%  of  GDP  by  2010  will  require  additional  reforms  to  tax  policy  and  tax 
administration. The Department of Finance (DOF) is targeting an increase in tax administration 
efficiency that would add tax revenue collections of up to 0.3% of GDP per year from 2008 to 
2010. To accomplish this target, BIR has developed a comprehensive tax administration reform 
program up to 2010, but implementation has been delayed and is much slower than expected. 
This  is  partly  due  to  the  complexity  of  the  reform  program  and  the  fact  that  BIR’s  budgetary 
resources for long-term reforms are critically constrained as reflected in the continuous decline 
in BIR operating costs per employee since 2000 (Appendix 5). Staff resistance, vested interests, 
and corruption have also contributed to the slow start to reform as it is rolled out to the regional 
tax offices. Staff resistance and corruption are intertwined with BIR’s resource constraints. For 
example,  starting  salaries  of  legal  staff  at  BIR  is  P12,000  per  month  compared  with  P32,000 
(plus  P24,000  allowances)  for  legal  staff  at  the  central  bank.  Thus,  the  Government  must 
address longer-term resource constraints at BIR.22 A draft bill has been submitted to Congress 
that if passed will allow BIR to set salaries closer to market values. In the short term, BIR should 
focus  its  efforts  on  priority  areas  of  tax  administration  that  are  likely  to  achieve  the  biggest 
efficiency gains in the short to medium term. These include reforming and increasing the rates 
of  excise  taxes  in  2009,  and  rationalizing  investment  incentives  once  Congress  passes  the 
revised bill (expected in 2008).23 The anticorruption revenue programs—“run after tax evaders” 
(RATE)  in  BIR  and  “run  after  tax  smugglers”  (RATS)  in  BOC—have  made  some  progress  in 
identifying  tax  evasion  cases  and  increasing  tax  prosecutions.  But  BIR  and  BOC  will  need  to 
institutionalize  these  programs  within  their  organizations  to  ensure  they  become  effective 
deterrents to tax evasion. At the same time, institutional linkages will need to be strengthened 
between  BIR,  Department  of  Justice,  and  Court  of  Tax  Appeals;  and  capacity  developed  to 
ensure  effective,  coordinated  effort  in  tax  prosecution.  Strengthening  the  revenue-forecasting 
capabilities  of  DOF  (and  the  Bureau  of  Treasury)  is  important  to  ensure  realistic  tax  revenue 
forecasts. In response to weak tax revenue performance in the first semester of 2007, ADB is 
providing  TA  to  BIR  and  DOF  to  strengthen  revenue-enhancing  measures,  enforcement,  and 
prosecution of tax evaders (footnote 4).24

Trade  Facilitation.  In  the  early  1990s,  the  Philippines  undertook  major  trade  policy 
reforms including reducing average import tariff rates to about 8% in 2000, and dismantled most 
(but not all) nontariff barriers. Trade facilitation costs remain relatively  high. Depending on the 
product, exporters and importers must deal with several different government agencies to obtain 
permits. In all, about 40 different government agencies issue regulations or permits on exporting 
and  importing  goods.  Until  recently,  the  Department  of  Agriculture  had  five  separate  agencies

of  the  Kyoto  Protocol  for  Customs  that  promotes  transparency  and  efficiency  in  customs

customs  information  management  system,  which  promotes  arms-length  transactions  between 
importers and customs officials, and produces timely trade and customs data collection. As an 
archipelago nation, relatively low trade facilitation costs are crucial for competitiveness (para 33).

34. 
Poverty. About 27.6 million Filipinos, or 33% of the population were poor in 2006. The 
poor are heavily concentrated in agriculture, or the nonwage (informal) sector. In contrast, the 
nonpoor  are  more  likely  to  be  in  wage  employment  in  the  nonagriculture  sector.  While  the 
nonpoor are more likely to benefit from remittances sent by family members working overseas, 
ADB  staff  estimates  still  suggest  that  remittances  reduced  the  national  poverty  rate  by  
5 percentage points (Supplementary Appendix B). Disparities in the incidence of poverty across 
regions are significant. A negative relationship exists between subnational per capita GDP and 
poverty  incidence.  Poverty  incidence  is  low  in  the  National  Capital  Region,  Central  and 
Southern  Luzon,  Ilocos,  and  Central  Visayas,  where  per  capita  GDP  is  above  the  national 
median. Much higher poverty incidence is recorded in regions with relatively low per capita GDP, 
such  as  the  Autonomous  Region  of  Muslim  Mindanao,  Mindanao,  Bicol,  and  Eastern  and 
Western  Visayas.  A  look  at  poverty  magnitude—the  total  number  of  poor  people—presents  a 
somewhat different picture of regional disparities, as the areas with low poverty incidence tend 
to have larger populations, and vice versa. About one in five poor Filipinos live in the National 
Capital Region and the surrounding provinces (e.g., Batangas, Cavite, Laguna, Quezon, Rizal, 
Zambales). 
 
35.  Millennium Development Goals. The 2007 midterm progress report on the Millennium 
Development Goals (footnote 31) indicates that halfway to the 2015 target year, the Philippines 
has  made  considerable  progress  in  some  areas  (particularly  in  reducing  poverty;  improving 
gender  equality;  reducing  child  mortality;  combating  HIV,  AIDS,  malaria,  and  other  diseases; 
and improving access to safe drinking water and sanitary toilet facilities). However, challenges 
continue  in  the  areas  of  universal  access  to  education,  maternal  mortality,  and  access  to 
reproductive health services. Access to primary education has dropped. The net enrolment rate 
fell  from  97%  in  2000  to  84%  in  the  2005/06  school  year,  representing  a  setback  to  the  2015 
target  of  universal  access.  The  report  shows  uneven  progress  and  wide  disparities  across 
regions. Most of the lagging regions and provinces are in Mindanao, while the frontrunners are 
in  Luzon.  The  National  Capital  Region,  Ilocos  Region  (Region  1),  Cagayan  Valley  (Region  2), 
Western Visayas (Region 6), Central Visayas (Region 7), and Southern Mindanao (Region 11) 
consistently lead for most indicators. The rest of the country’s regions lag in most of the targets.

36.  Measures  to  Address  Poverty.  Poverty  reduction  programs  should  focus  on  the 
dimensions of poverty highlighted in paras.  34 and 35. The Government will need to increase 
investment  in  education  and  infrastructure,  particularly  in  the  MDG  lagging  regions.  Targeted 
poverty reduction programs, such as the proposed conditional cash transfer (CCT) program, are 
a  useful  way  to  link  social  assistance  with  human  capital  development.  The  success  of  this 
demand-side  intervention  will,  to  a  large  extent,  depend  on  supply-side  readiness,  i.e.,  the

Catching Up with the MDGs. Fiscal austerity measures introduced from 2001 to 2006 
37. 
to reduce the Government deficit disproportionately hurt social policy expenditures. This is one 
of the reasons the Philippines is having difficulty meeting some of its MDG targets, particularly 
those in education and health. During 2001–2005, the share of central Government spending on 
the  social  sector  was  22%  in  the  Philippines,  compared  with  45%  in  Thailand  and  37%  in 
Malaysia (footnote 32). The share of public expenditure on education fell from 3.0% of GDP in 
1991 to 2.7% in 2005, as compared to 6.2% in Malaysia and 4.2% in Thailand. In 2004, public 
expenditure on health as a share of GDP  was 1.4% in the Philippines compared with 2.2% in 
Malaysia and 2.3% in Thailand.32 Weak governance and inequality in resource allocation have 
also  contributed  to  poor  social  sector  outcomes.  The  Government  is  well  aware  of  these 
problems and is committed to improving quality and access to basic education and health care, 
reversing recent declines in performance. The 2007 budget allocated substantial real increases 
to  the  social  sector  (6%  over  the  2006  budget).  The  proposed  budget  for  2008  increased 
allocations  to  the  education  and  health  sectors  by  about  11%.  The  increased  share  for  the 
Department  of  Education  (DepEd)  will  provide  larger  allocations  for  teacher  recruitment, 
textbooks,  new  school  buildings,  and  repair  and  maintenance  of  existing  schools;  this  is  to 
widen  coverage  and  improve  quality.  The  Government  intends  to  move  to  a  needs-based 
formula for allocating school funding. In the health sector, the Government adopted the Formula 
One for Health implementation framework for health sector reforms in the medium term (2005–
2010).  The  overall  goal  is  to  improve  the  quality,  efficiency,  effectiveness,  and  equity  of  the 
health system, particularly for the poor. ADB’s Health Sector Development Program (footnote 12) 
offers  one  example  of  how  systematic  provincial  public  expenditure  reviews  and  the  use  of 
programmatic initiatives can help effect improvements to local service delivery. 
 
Social Protection. ADB actively participated in policy dialogue on social sector issues in 
38. 
2007 primarily through the PDF Working Group on MDGs and Social Progress. In a number of 
working sessions in 2006 and 2007, the subgroup on social protection, led by the Department of 
Social Welfare and Development (DSWD), refined the definition of social protection, using the 
ADB  definition  as  a  model.  In  February  2007,  NEDA  issued  Social  Development  Committee 
Resolution No. 1, series of 2007, on Adopting a Philippine Definition of Social Protection. The 
resolution recognizes the need for a common framework in designing and implementing social 
protection programs, and sets out that social protection “constitutes policies and programs that 
seek to reduce poverty and vulnerability to risks and enhance the social status and rights of the 
marginalized  by  promoting  and  protecting  livelihood  and  employment,  protecting  against 
hazards and sudden loss of income, and improving people’s capacity to manage risks.” The four 
components of social protection are (i) labor market programs, or measures aimed at enhancing 
employment  opportunities  and  protection,  and  the  rights  and  welfare  of  workers;  (ii)  social 
insurance, or programs that seek to mitigate income risks by pooling resources and spreading 
risks across time and classes; (iii) social welfare, or preventive and development interventions 
that seek to support the minimum basic requirements of the poor; and (iv) social safety nets and 
stop-gap mechanisms, or urgent responses that address effects of economic shocks, disasters,

Conditional  Cash  Transfer  Program.  With  the  aim  of  refining  targeted  programs  for 
39. 
poverty  reduction,  in  2007,  DSWD  designed  a  new  CCT  program,  known  as  the  Pantawid 
Pamilyang  Pilipino  Program.  The  program  falls  under  the  social  welfare  category  of  the 
Philippine definition of social protection. With more than a decade of implementation experience 
and  proven  results,  particularly  in  Latin  America,  CCT  programs  provide  income  support 
conditional  on  human  capital  investments,  such  as  sending  children  to  school  or  attending 
health  clinics,  thus  reducing  the  risk  of  future  poverty.  CCTs  have  additional  benefits  that 
include  reduced  child  labor  and,  as  cash  benefits  are  often  paid  directly  to  mothers,  the 
empowerment of women. The program goal is to build the human capital of children aged 0–14 
from the poorest families. The cash grants will be linked to five conditions: (i) pregnant women 
receive  pre-  and  postnatal  care  beginning  in  the  1st  trimester  of  pregnancy,  and  the  birth  is 
attended by a skilled health professional; (ii) parents attend parent effectiveness service classes; 
regular  preventive  health  checkups  and  vaccines;  
(iii)  children  aged  0–5 
(iv) children aged 3–5 attend day-care or preschool programs; and (v) children aged 6–14 are 
enrolled  in  school  and  demonstrate  at  least  an  85%  attendance  rate.  These  conditions  are 
selected to address the persistent human development bottlenecks, including high infant, child, 
and  maternal  mortality  rates;  malnutrition;  low  completion  rates  in  primary  education  and  low

and  a  proxy  means  test.  DSWD  recognizes  that  using  uniform,  objective,  and  transparent 
criteria to select beneficiaries is crucial for the success of the program. With the recent external 
price  shocks,  the  Government  has  decided  to  scale  up  the  program  to  cover  321,000 
households nationwide.

Assessments of the Philippines’ public procurement reforms show substantial progress, 
as mandated by the procurement law and the issuance of implementing rules. The empowered 
GPPB  is  overseeing  implementation  to  make  sure  that  transparency,  efficiency,  and

Fiscal Crisis and Consolidation 

Lack  of  Fiscal  Discipline.  The  national  Government  has  posted  only  four  budget 
3. 
surpluses in 37 years; three were in the 1990s. Fiscal indiscipline coupled with poor monetary 
policy management (until 1993 when the central bank was reformed) were the main contributors 
to macro instability from the late 1970s to 2004 (Figure A4.2). In 2005, the Philippines emerged 
from  another  serious  fiscal  situation  (from  1998  to  2004)  when  budget  revenues  dropped 
significantly  leading  to  suppressed expenditure  in  the  social  sectors  and  substantial  decline  in 
public  sector  real  wages.1 The  deficit  reached  5.2%  of  GDP  and  the  nonfinance  public  sector 
debt exceeded 100% of GDP in the same year. The Government has restored macroeconomic 
stability  and  maintained  it  through  fiscal  discipline.  The  cornerstone  and  the  measure  with  the 
highest revenue impact was the reform of value-added tax in November 2005, which extended 
the value-added tax base to energy products, and increased the rate from 10% to 12% effective 
February  2006.  Other  measures  supporting  fiscal  consolidation  include  increasing  (i)  excise 
taxes on alcohol and tobacco products by 30% at the end of 2004 (although not fully indexed to 
inflation),  (ii)  the  corporate  income  tax  rate  from  32%  to  35%,  and  (iii)  electricity  tariffs.  As  a 
consequence  of  these  reforms,  tax  revenues  grew  by  over  1.3  percentage  points  of  GDP  in 
2006,  the  national  government  deficit  fell  to  1.1%  of  GDP  from  2.7%  in  2005,  and  the 
consolidated public sector budget (which includes the balances of the government-owned and  
-controlled corporations) turned in a surplus for the first time in almost a decade, aided by the 
financial improvement of the National Power Corporation. Fiscal consolidation continued in 2007 
with the national government deficit falling to 0.2% of GDP and the consolidated public sector 
deficit remaining in balance for a second consecutive year. Tax revenues in 2007 grew by 8%, 
short  of  the  budget  target  of  14.8%.  Nevertheless,  total  revenues  grew  by  14%  aided  by 
proceeds from privatization of state-owned assets, demonstrating the Government’s resolve in 
maintaining fiscal discipline.

2003  was  entirely  due  to  expenditure  suppression  (Table  A5.1).  In  2006,  revenues  played  a

Medium-term  sustainable  priority  spending  requires  improving  efficiency  in  public 
expenditure  management  by  ensuring  a  balanced  public  expenditure  program  for  capital 
spending and recurrent expenditures, as well as for discretionary and nondiscretionary spending 
items (interest payments and wages). This will require continuing to reorient spending to priority 
sectors  of  education,  health,  and  public  infrastructure.  Implementing  improved  systems  for 
public  expenditure  management  including  the  medium-term  expenditure  framework,  which 
aligns  the  budget  planning  process  with  strategic  objectives  and  priorities,  is  integral  to 
improving  efficiency  in  public  expenditure  management.  Progress  is  being  made.  The 
Department of Budget and Management has incorporated the medium-term framework into the 
2008 budget including forward estimates for a 3-year rolling period produced for all 23 national 
agencies.  It  is  now  in  the  process  of  computerizing  the  computation  of  forward  estimates  and 
will  roll  it  out  to  priority  line  ministries.  Recent  diagnostic  assessments  carried  out  by  the 
International Monetary Fund, World Bank, and ADB under the DPSP identify several core areas 
to be addressed with aid support beginning with budget preparation through to budget execution 
including  scope  to  improve  cash  management,  establish  internal  controls  and  audit,  and 
strengthen budget reporting processes. Integral to this will be the development of an integrated 
government  financial  management  system.  The  ADB-supported  Health  Sector  Development 
Program  offers  one  example  of  how  systematic  provincial  public  expenditure  reviews  and  the 
use of programmatic initiatives can help effect change.

Debt  Sustainability. Public debt as a share of GDP has declined to levels of the early 
1990s, but remains high by regional standards (Table A5 and Figure A5.2b). At the end of 2007,

101% in 2003. National government debt accounts for the bulk of the national financial sector 
public debt and is estimated at $89 billion or 59% of GDP in 2007, down from 64% in 2006. A

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Philippines: The DPSP policy areas largely correspond with

MTPDP mission is to “fight poverty by building prosperity for the greatest number of Filipino people.”  
 
The Government has made substantial progress in addressing fiscal consolidation and is now shifting to ensuring sustainable 
fiscal policy by enhancing tax revenues over the longer term. This is necessary to increase social expenditures. In 2008 the 
Government will operate a budget deficit of no more than 1% of GDP, 0.5% of GDP in 2009, and balanced budget by 2010. 
This  ensures  fiscal  discipline  while  at  the  same  time  provides  flexibility  on  fiscal  policy  to  protect  social  spending,  such  as 
during the recent episode of food price inflation. The value-added tax reform is producing results, as well  as the intensified 
collection  performance  by  the  Bureau  of  Internal  Revenue  and  Bureau  of  Customs  in  the  first  semester  of  2008.  The 
increased revenue from reforms in 2006 was used to reduce public debt, and to finance infrastructure and social services in

B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
1.  Key Issues  
The sustained economic expansion is beginning to impact the Philippines' stubbornly high unemployment rate for the first time 
in a decade. Lower long-term economic growth coupled with relatively restrictive labor regulations meant higher longer-term 
unemployment in the Philippines compared with its regional neighbors. In 2007, the unemployment rate fell to an average of 
7.3% from 7.9% in 2006, although the economic slowdown in 2008 has raised the average unemployment rate. Progress on 
poverty reduction and income inequality has been less clear. The 2006 family income and expenditure survey indicates the 
headcount poverty rate increased by 3 percentage points from 30% in 2003 to 33% in 2006. 
 
2. Design Features. With support through the DPSP, the Government is addressing these issues of poverty and vulnerability 
to  poverty  by  reforming  social  protection  programs,  introducing  the  conditional  cash  transfer  program,  and  increasing 
spending on the social sectors. 
 
C.  Poverty Impact Analysis for Policy-Based Lending  
The  DPSP  supports  the  Government  to  address  these  issues  through  the  program’s  social  sector  component.  The  DPSP 
supports  increased  spending  on  the  social  sector  in  areas  where  the  Philippines  is  lagging  in  its  Millennium  Development 
Goals (MDGs) (e.g., education). It also supports the design and implementation of the conditional cash transfer program that 
links assistance with outcomes in family education and health.

Issues 

 
Medium-term  sustainable  priority  spending  requires  improving  the  efficiency  of  PEM. 
2. 
Key  challenges  for  the  Government  are  to  balance  the  public  expenditure  program  between 
capital  spending  and  recurrent  expenditures,  as  well  as  between  discretionary  and 
nondiscretionary  spending  items  (local  government  unit  [LGU]  transfers,  wages,  and  interest
